Award.AwardTitle: Institutional Competing Logics: Local Context vs. National Identity in United Way Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the Principal Investigators will examine the local variation that occurs as part of a top-down effort within a highly institutionalized national system. Institutional theory suggests that local organizations will adopt new national practices to remain legitimate in their larger field of activity, leading to organizational homogeneity; however there is growing interest in the role of local institutions in shaping alternative local responses. As a result local organizations may remain only loosely coupled to broader change efforts. The investigators will explore to what extent change has occurred in local United Way systems over the last decade as part of the move to Community Impact and how such change is associated with shifting community logics and resource environments.

In terms of broader impacts, this research is particularly important during the current sustained recession because in the face of severe economic challenges organizations may face increased pressures to resolve the tensions between national legitimacy and local resource demands. The results of the study will potentially advance practical understanding about change in institutionalized systems. Also, the research team will create a publicly available hierarchical database that matches all local United Ways within the United Way system and the community contexts in which they are embedded to the nonprofits that they fund. This asset will be of value to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study explores variation in local United Way practices in the context of United Way Worldwide’s move to Community Impact.   This project involved the construction of a unique database drawn from a variety of secondary data sources that captures all allocations made to United Way partners, the characteristics of community partnerships and the socio-demographic characteristics of the communities in which they are located. Analysis of this dataset has offered unique insights into organizational theory, particularly how local organizations respond to national mandates for change and the impact of the competitive environment on organizational performance. Our findings expand our understanding of how local conditions influence relationships between United Ways and their partners. Our findings suggest that United Ways have strong ties to partners that they depend upon to accomplish their mission and secure resources for the larger system. These dependencies create barriers to change, which are particularly strong for UWs that have strong connections in their community. In times of fiscal stress, United Ways are more likely to break such long standing ties. In addition, we have found that United Ways face diverse competitive pressures that influence their local partnerships. Competition between fundraising organizations does affect organizational performance; however, there is an aspect of competition, which is synergistic. United Ways located in communities with very strong local philanthropic institutions may be successful in building the field and a culture of philanthropy. In such communities, the ties that bind United Ways to their partners may be even stronger and more difficult to change. In conclusion we find that although local United Ways face strong pressure to change from the national system, the degree to which change occurs at the local level is dependent upon local resource relationships and the competitive vs. mutualistic environment in which local United Ways operate.

These findings suggest that top-down efforts to promote local change will not be uniformly adopted. Local efforts to respond to changing local needs will also be hampered by long standing resource dependencies between local United Ways and their partners. While this research took place in the context of local United Way systems, these findings are applicable to a variety of other community based systems in which organizations develop long term relationships and become dependent upon each other to carry out their mission and secure resources.

In addition, the project involved the construction of a unique data set that captures the allocations made to partner agencies by all local United Ways in the US. The United Way is the largest single funder of health and human services in most local communities. This rich data set provides a base line to understand local, private funding patterns, the determinants of allocation decisions, and how these funding decisions adapt to changes in local socio-economic conditions. As local communities rely more heavily upon local philanthropic systems to respond to community needs, this dataset can offer important insights into the capacity of local systems to respond to changing local conditions.
